conclusion: The problem involves analyzing a displacement-time graph to determine the particle's motion and identify moments when the speed equals 5 m/s.

The graph shows displacement x (in meters) as a function of time t (in seconds). Initial displacement at t = 0 is approximately 10 m, at t â‰ˆ 2.5 s the displacement becomes 0, and by t = 4 s the displacement reaches approximately -10 m.

For a displacement-time graph, the slope represents velocity (v = dx/dt). Positive slope indicates motion in the positive direction, negative slope indicates motion in the negative direction, and a horizontal curve indicates the particle is momentarily at rest.
From 0 to ~2.5 seconds, the curve has a negative slope, so the particle moves in the negative direction (velocity is negative).
At ~2.5 seconds, the particle passes through the origin (x = 0).
From ~2.5 to 4 seconds, the particle continues moving in the negative direction as the curve maintains a negative slope.
Speed is the magnitude of velocity, so we need to find when |v| = 5 m/s. Velocity v is determined by the slope of the displacement-time curve.
The slope of the curve is initially negative and gradually increases in magnitude (steeper downward). Later, the slope begins to level off as the curve approaches -10 m.
The slope appears to pass through -5 m/s at two points: once during the early part of the motion and once during the later part.
The slope never reaches +5 m/s as the curve never has a positive slope.
The particle's speed equals 5 m/s at approximately two moments within the 0-4 second interval, both times with a negative velocity (moving in the negative direction).
